channel.title: Programs
channel.description:
Well.. Just out of curiosity. What kind of programs are you guys making with these hexdecimals and what not. I want to get used to using them... What should I be doing to put me into practice of using hexdecimals binary, enums and 2d arrays.
Not so sure if ANY of that made sense..

item.title: Programs
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:17, topic:446273”][quote author=t4 link=topic=549129.msg4027719#msg4027719 date=1340482850]

Get into ROM hacking or anything that uses bit masks.

You can modify ROM;o?

if they’re digital copies, yes; but real ROMs cannot be modified (ie, the actual gameboy cartridge)

auhtorized cartridges*

I’ve made a cartridge I can flash with any game I want.

i was under the impression that gameboy games were programmed via hardware? (since that’s how BIOSs are programmed). or is what you’re saying if you have a cartridge that isn’t an official one (allows writing).
[/quote]The latter - a flash cart is what they’re called. However, unlike GBA games, GB/C games don’t have BIOS operations. They’re very straight-forward and easy to create & modify.[/quote]

Exactly. I haven’t experimented much with the GBA, but know that there are some integrity checks that can be performed to prevent ROM hacking (RMA stuff I believe).

Read full topic

(since that’s how BIOSs are programmed). or is what you’re saying if you have a cartridge that isn’t an official one (allows writing).[/quote]The latter - a flash cart is what they’re called. However, unlike GBA games, GB/C games don’t have BIOS operations. They’re very straight-forward and easy to create & modify.

item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“ravekitty, post:6, topic:446273”][quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=549129.msg4025608#msg4025608 date=1340313110]
Any type of program, really.
[/quote]
I’m not looking very deeply into it…
So I don’t quite see where I would use it.[/quote]it’s often used where representing the actual state of data’s constituent bits is more important than the value that is represented by the combined states of the bits.

item.description:
@T41 wrote:

why are you so obsessed over binary representation?

here’s a nice article to help you understand why hex is used:

digiassn.blogspot.de

Why do we use Hexadecimal?

Thanks to OSNews.com for pointing out this site aimed at teaching C. While the site is still too new and the number of articles there are ...
